title: Diabetic Foot Ulcer Case Study: Mr. Johnson
clinical_history: Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old male with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with a non-healing ulcer on the plantar surface of his right foot, which he first noticed 6 weeks ago. The ulcer has been gradually increasing in size and has not responded to conservative treatment. Mr. Johnson has a history of neuropathy and has experienced numbness and tingling in his feet for several years. He has also had previous episodes of foot infections and has undergone several debridements.

nprs.affected_area: pain and tenderness at the ulcer site
burning sensation and numbness in the foot

aggrevating_factors: weight-bearing activities, tight shoes, and walking long distances
picture: a 2cm x 3cm ulcer on the plantar surface of the right foot with surrounding erythema and edema
easing_factors: rest, elevation of the foot, and off-loading pressure
past_history: history of foot infections, previous debridements, and a below-knee amputation of the left leg 5 years ago
medical_history: type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia
personal_history: married, lives alone, and has limited mobility due to his condition. He is a retired accountant and has a sedentary lifestyle.
imaging: X-rays of the right foot showing no signs of osteomyelitis or Charcot changes
